titleStmt.title: Bloudy nevves from Kent being a relation of the great fight at Rochester and Maidstone, betwixt the Parliaments army under the comand of the Lord Generall Fairfax, and the Kentish forces commanded by Generall Hales. With the number that were slain and taken prisoners, and a list of the Kentish commanders, and the town of Maidstone taken. Squire Hales Generall. Sir Thomas Peyton Lieutenant Generall. The Lord Goring. Col. Washington. Sir George Lisle. Col. Dudley. Sir William Compton. Col. Hacker. Col. Tracy. Col. Hales. Col. Dorrell. Col. Godfrey. Col. Hammond. Col. Hardresse. Col. Lee. Likewise, the proceedings and resolution of Col. Cook and his regiment of butchers.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 10 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

titleStmt.title: Bloudy nevves from Kent being a relation of the great fight at Rochester and Maidstone, betwixt the Parliaments army under the comand of the Lord Generall Fairfax, and the Kentish forces commanded by Generall Hales. With the number that were slain and taken prisoners, and a list of the Kentish commanders, and the town of Maidstone taken. Squire Hales Generall. Sir Thomas Peyton Lieutenant Generall. The Lord Goring. Col. Washington. Sir George Lisle. Col. Dudley. Sir William Compton. Col. Hacker. Col. Tracy. Col. Hales. Col. Dorrell. Col. Godfrey. Col. Hammond. Col. Hardresse. Col. Lee. projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: BLOUDY NEVVES FROM KENT BEING A Relation of the great Fight at Rochester and Maid≈øtone, betwixt the Parliaments Army under the comand of the Lord Generall Fairfax, and the Kenti≈øh Forces commanded by Generall Hales.
With the number that were ≈ølain and taken pri≈øoners, and a Li≈øt of the Kenti≈øh Commanders, and the town of Maid≈øtone taken.
Likewi≈øe, the proceedings and Re≈øolution of Col. Cook and his Regiment of Butchers.
London, Printed for R. W. MDCXLVIII.

div.head: BLOUDY NEWES FROM KENT
div.p:
SInce my la≈øt, here hath hapned a grea ‚Ä¢ Engagement betwixt the two Armies, the manner thus; The Lord Generall having entred Kent, and forced the Enemy to withdraw from Deptford, Greenwich, Blacke-Heath, and other places, they pur≈øued teem towards Roche≈øter, where the Enemy with the greatest part of their Forces made a ≈øtand, and drew up into two di≈øtinct
Bodies and after ≈øome con≈øultation, they re≈øolved not to fight in the field, but to make good Roche≈øter bridge, and the River and Foords at Maid≈øtone, and Alsbury: this was unanimon≈øly a≈ø≈øented to, and the Kenti≈øh forces pre≈øently marched over Roche≈øter bridg, and left as many hor≈øe and foot to defend the place, as the town could contain and the re≈øt of the forces marched to make good the pa≈øsages at Maid≈øtone, and other places; and in the Rivers where the hor≈øe might po≈ø≈øible get through, they fa≈øtned barrows, and many ≈øharp ≈øtakes in the bottome. At Roche≈øter they be≈øtirred them≈øelves to the almost, to make their Forti≈øications good; drawing us the Bridge, and ca≈øting up workes where need was, & planted 4 piece of Ordnance at the bridge foot: they al≈øo planted 40 of their greatest pieces upon the workes neer the River, ad about the town for the defence of them≈øelves again≈øt the Army, whom they expected hourly; and upon Thur≈øday night la≈øt, the Lord Generall with his forces drew neer the town, which gave a ≈øtrong allarm to the Kenti≈øh-men, but yet they re≈øolved to ≈øtand to it the army was divided into parties, ≈øome of them being de≈øigned to fal on at Maid≈øtone, another party at Alesford, and the main body to fall an at Roche≈øter, which they did, and faught gallantly again≈øt the Kenti≈øh-forces at Roche≈øter bridge, the K ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ti≈øhmen al≈øo ≈øtood it out ≈øtoutly, and often cryed out, hey for King
Charles, this di≈øpute la≈øted long, and many men were ≈øtain on both ≈øides, it is ≈øaid, about 500. ≈øome of them being per≈øons of quality, as a Colonel, a Captane, and many others; like wi≈øe many are dangerou≈øly wounded, & it is feared, much bloud will be ≈øpilt before the bridge can be taken: this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe by ≈øome is thought to be much greater then it is; for they give out, that when the Parliaments Forces were ingaging at Roche≈øter bridg that the ≈øhip called the Swallow lying above the bridg, and the Rainbow lying below the bridge, charged with ca≈øe-≈øhot, di≈øcharged them≈øelves upo the Parliaments Forces, and killed 500. of them, in≈øomuch that the ≈øouldiery were forced to retreat; which the Kenti≈øh men perceiving, ≈øallied out of Roche≈øter with their whole body of how≈øe, pur≈øued them, took 12, piece of Ordnance, ≈øome arms ≈øome pri≈øoners, all their Carriages, Al≈øo they ≈øay, that Col. Barke≈øtead, Col. Rich, and divers others are ≈ølain; but I give you this Relation not for any real truth I ≈øuppo≈øe to be in it, but that you may ≈øee the various rumours that are ≈øpead abroad, therefore you may take it rather for a report of tho≈øe that would have it ≈øo, then for a certainty that it is ≈øo.

Many Butchers are gone to the Kenti≈øh forces, mo≈øt of them from London, and ≈øome from other places one Cook is their Colonel, who leads them on, and incourages them, their Regiment cou≈øi≈øts of about 600. their Colours are red, and their Motto, For Ring Charles and Kent, in the upper end of their Cullers is the ≈øtation of the Butchers Steele in white,

div.head: Another Letter touching the Kenti≈øh Army.
div.p: THE Kenti≈øh Army is retreated as far as Roche≈øter, Maid≈øtone, and other towns adjacent, they con≈øi≈øt of about 14000. but are divided into two Bodies, mo≈øt of them being armed; but they cannot coucord and agree about their Commanders in chief, ≈øome ≈øay, that they de≈øire Col. Wa≈øhigton may be their Generall; others give out, that they will have the Lord Culpepper.

This day the Generall had a Randezvouz upon the Heath beyond this town, where appeared of hor≈øe and foot 8000. The Kenti≈øh-men have ≈øent Propo≈øitions to the General, touching a treaty, but the Generall returned an≈øwer, that hee knew not of any order of Parliament directing him to treat, and whereas he finds the Gentlemen of Kent, and others in Arms, and per≈øi≈øting therein, without, and again≈øt the authority of Parliament, and doing many Acts of Ho≈øtility, to the great dammage of their Neighbours, he cannot captiulate while they are ≈øo in arms, nor lo≈øe time in pro≈øecution; but if they forthwith lay down, and go home, he doubt not but
the Parliament with pardon the ≈øeduced, and puni≈øhe the ≈øeducers for example to others.
The Regiment, and are very numerous in hor≈øe, few men of quality to be ≈øeen, but as is apprehended, gathered in Armes; ≈øome skirmi≈øhes haye been and at ≈øeverall times neer 100. pri≈øoners taken.

A ≈ømall party of Col. Riches hor≈øe ≈øallying out, met with a party of the Kenti≈øh foot, fought with them, and put them to a rout, taking 36 pri≈øoners, with the lo≈ø≈øe of one man, having but 7 in number.

But on Wedne≈øday la≈øt a party of the Kenti≈øh men came up unto a Guard of the Parliaments Forces, they fought well, divers of them were ≈ølain, others taken, among the re≈øt two young Gentlemen, who were brave in Gold and Silver Lace, with whom the Souldiers changed. The Generall hath a party of hor≈øe in the wild of Kent, who de≈øire to relieve Dover Ca≈øtle be≈øieged by them, to whom are joyned ≈øome hundreds of the Kenti≈øh, who have made ≈øome ≈øpoyl among the other Kenti≈øh, and have taken Col. Culpepper, and many others. They ≈øay there is with the Kenti≈øh-men one of the Gorings, and that they increa≈øe hourly.

postscript.head: POSTSCRIPT.
postscript.p: SIR, Since the writing of my la≈øt, we have received intelligence, that the party of hor≈øe that went to relieve Dover Ca≈øtle, have had a great fight with the Kenti≈øh Hor≈øe neer Canterbury, and have taken divers pri≈øoners, and killed many, with the lo≈ø≈øe of two or thee men, and have totally routed the whole party. They al≈øo skirmi≈øhed with another party of the Kenti≈øh Hor≈øe, commanded by a Colonel formerly in the Kings Army, and after ≈øome ≈øhort di≈øpute, took the ≈øaid Colonell, and 30 of his men pri≈øoners, The great Fort at Dover is re-taken, and now in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of he Parliaments Forces.

list.head: A Li≈øt of the Commanders in chief belonging to the Kenti≈øh Army.

postscript.p: It is reported, that their Army is 16000. or thereabouts, and do dayly increa≈øe. Upon Tue≈øday la≈øt about 30. eminent Commanders came out of E≈øsex, and joyned with the Kenti≈øh Forces. It is ≈øaid they expect 5000. from Surry.

Upon Fryday being the 2. of this in≈øtant June, the Parliaments Army fell upon the Kenti≈øh forces at Maid≈øtone, and after a de≈øperate and bloudy fight, took the ≈øaid town, together with 200 pri≈øoners, and 200 hor≈øe: there was ≈ølain neer upon 200. of the enemy with the lo≈ø≈øe of 80 men.
